item.title: Getting started
item.description: Chapter 1 Getting started with Shiny Creating a Shiny app The most straightforward way of creating a new Shiny app is to use R Studio. From the menu, choose, File, New, Shiny Web App. Choose a suitable name for your app (e.g. “gapminder”). item.title: Reactive data
item.description: In this example we only use the filtered gapminder data in a single place - to plot the graph. For this reason we did the filtering within the renderPlot() function. Let’s add another output to the app; we’ll show which country is the richest displayed on the graph, and what its GDP per capita is. This means that we’ll be using the gapminder data filtered by year and country in two places; on the graph itself and in the logic where we work out what the richest country is.

item.title: About
item.description: This site is for the RSE 2018 conference workshop on Shiny. It is written by David Mawdsley, with help from Joshua Woodcock and Louise Lever, who are all Research Software Engineers at the University of Manchester. Thanks to Christopher Woods at the University of Bristol for his mentoring and comments, and to Gerard Capes and Ann Gledson for beta testing the course. This site is written using Hugo, the learn theme, and hosted on github.
